header.name: chaos/preprocessor/recursion/revive.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines a macro used to re-enable a macro name that was previously disabled (i.e. "painted blue").

macro.abstract: The macro re-enables a macro name preprocessing token that was previously disabled.

usage.param: The macro name to be re-enabled. This macro name must have a derivative form suffixed with _ID that is a nullary macro that expands to macro (i.e. an indirection macro).

macro.para:
This macro concatenates _ID to macro and invokes the result with nullary parentheses.
(macro, _ID)()
It is intended that an appropriate indirection macro exists for macro. For example, assuming that macro is ABC, then ABC_ID() should expand to ABC.

Macro name preprocessing tokens get permanently disabled when they are created in (or just pass through) the context created by the macro to which they refer. Even when a disabled macro name is no longer inside that context, it remains disabled--permanently. Hence, the creation of a new preprocessing token is required, which is what does through concatenation and an indirection macro. Note that if a macro name preprocessing token is "revived" when the context is still present, it will just immediately get disabled again. Consequently, this macro is not a substitute for recursion.
